tn.text: The events in this chapter take place after the Persians conquered the Babylonians and Darius the Mede began to rule in Babylon.
"King Darius decided"
"one hundred and twenty provincial governors" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])
The word "them" refers to the 120 provincial governors.

tn.ref: so that the king should suffer no loss
tn.text: "so that nothing should be stolen from the king" or "so that no one would steal anything from the king"
"excelled above" or "was more capable than"
Here "spirit" refers to Daniel. It means he had was unusually capable. AT: "he was and exceptional person" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
"impressive" or "excellent"
"to give him authority over" or "to put him in charge of"

tn.ref: Then the other chief administrators and the provincial governors ... for the kingdom
tn.text: The other administrators were jealous of Daniel. This can be made explicit. AT: "Then the other chief administrators and the provincial governors became jealous. So they looked for mistakes in the work Daniel did for the kingdom" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: No mistakes or negligence was found in him
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "They could find no mistakes or negligence in his work." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
overly looking your responsibilities
"to complain about Daniel"

tn.ref: brought a plan before the king
tn.text: "presented a plan to the king"
This was a normal way to greet a king.
"for 30 days" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])
"whoever makes a request"

tn.ref: that person must be thrown into the den of lions
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "your soldiers must throw that person into the den of lions" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
This may refer to a room or pit where lions were kept.
In verse 8, the administrators continue to speak to the king.
"according to the laws"
"cannot be canceled"

tn.ref: making the decree into a law
tn.text: "making the order into a law"

tn.ref: When Daniel learned that the document had been signed into law
tn.text: It is important to the story to state clearly that Daniel knew about the new law before he prayed to God.

tn.ref: now his windows were open in his upper room toward Jerusalem
tn.text: This is background information that explains how Daniel's enemies knew he was praying to God. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_background]])
"gave thanks to his God"
a plan with evil intent

tn.ref: Did you not make a decree ... lions?
tn.text: They asked this question to make the king confirm that he had made the decree.
"who makes a request"
This may refer to a room or pit where lions were kept. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:dan:06:06|6:7]].
"according to the law"
This is not a respectful way of referring to Daniel. They intentionally used this phrase to avoid giving Daniel the respect he was due as a chief administrator.

tn.ref: who is one of the people of the exile from Judah
tn.text: "who is an immagrant from Judah"
This idiom means he ignores the king. AT: "does not obey you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
Here "mind" refers to his thinking. AT: "he thought very hard about how" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This refers to mental labor, rather than to physical labor.
An additional sentence may be added here to aid in understanding. AT: "no decree ... can be changed. They must throw Daniel into the pit of lions" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"his soldiers went and got Daniel"
This may refer to a room or pit where lions were kept. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:dan:06:06|6:7]].
The king is expressing his desire for God to save Daniel.
"save you from the lions"
This may refer to a room or pit where lions were kept. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:dan:06:06|6:7]].

tn.ref: the king sealed it with his own signet ring and with the signet rings of his nobles ... concerning Daniel
tn.text: The function of the signet ring can be stated clearly. The king and the noblemen pressed their rings into a seal made of wax. AT: "the king pressed his signet ring into a wax seal, the nobles did this too. No one was allowed to break the seal and help Daniel" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: nothing might be changed concerning Daniel
tn.text: "no one could help Daniel"

tn.ref: he went through the night fasting
tn.text: This symbolic act showed that the king was worried about Daniel. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])

tn.ref: No entertainment was brought before him
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "He did not have anyone entertain him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
Sleep is spoken of as if it could run away from the king. AT: "he did not sleep at all that night" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
This may refer to a room or pit where lions were kept. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:dan:06:06|6:7]].
This can be stated in active form. AT: "He knows that I have done nothing wrong" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: I have done you no harm
tn.text: "I have not harmed you at all"
This may refer to a room or pit where lions were kept. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:dan:06:06|6:7]].

tn.ref: No harm was found on him
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "They did not find any wounds on Daniel" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
This may refer to a room or pit where lions were kept. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:dan:06:06|6:7]].
"Before they reached the floor of the lions' den"

tn.ref: broke all their bones to pieces
tn.text: "crushed their bones" (UDB)

Here "nations" and "languages" represent people from different nations who speak different languages. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:dan:03:03|3:4]]. AT: "people from different nations and who spoke different languages" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

King Darius wrote his message to his entire kingdom which was huge. Here it says "all the earth" to emphasis how large his kingdom was, though it did not include everyone on the earth. AT: "in his kingdom" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])
This is a form of greeting that is used to wish someone well in all areas of life.
This continues to state the message that Darius sent to everyone in his kingdom.
These two words are similar and can be combined. AT: "shake with fear" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
"the God that Daniel worships" (UDB)

tn.ref: he is the living God and lives forever
tn.text: The two phrases "the living God" and "lives forever" express the same concept, that God lives forever. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: his kingdom shall ... his dominion shall
tn.text: These two phrases are parallel, emphasizing how God's kingdom will never end. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: his kingdom shall not be destroyed
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "no one will destroy his kingdom" or "his kingdom will last forever" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: his dominion shall be to the end
tn.text: "he will rule forever"

tn.ref: he has kept Daniel safe from the strength of the lions
tn.text: "he has not allowed the strong lions to hurt Daniel"

tn.ref: during the reign of Darius and during the reign of Cyrus the Persian
tn.text: Cyrus the Persian was the king who ruled after Darius.
